en.whatThisMeansApplicantRespondent: The applicant is the person who has applied for a divorce (legally known as the petitioner). The respondent is their husband or wife.
en.whatThisMeansDetailsCoppied: These details are copied exactly from the marriage certificate, or a translation of the certificate if it's not in English. The names on the certificate are the names that the applicant and respondent used before the marriage.

en.whatThisMeansReasonForDivorceLegalGround: The only legal ground for divorce in England and Wales is if the marriage has broken down irretrievably.
en.whatThisMeansReasonForDivorceChosenReaso: The applicant had to choose a reason for the breakdown of the marriage (legally known as the 'fact') from the following list.
en.whatThisMeansReasonForDivorceBehaviourDe: The respondent has behaved in such a way that the applicant can't reasonably be expected to live with them any more.
en.whatThisMeansReasonForDivorceAdulteryDes: The respondent has committed adultery with a member of the opposite sex and the applicant finds it intolerable (unbearable) to live with them.
en.whatThisMeansReasonForDivorceSeparatedTw: The respondent agrees to a divorce and the applicant and respondent have been separated for 2 years or more.
en.whatThisMeansReasonForDivorceSeparatedFi: The applicant and respondent have been separated for 5 years or more.
en.whatThisMeansReasonForDivorceDesertionDe: The respondent abandoned the applicant (left without their agreement) more than 2 years ago.
en.whatThisMeansJurisdictionCourtsOfEngland: The courts of England and Wales must have the jurisdiction (the legal power) to be able to grant a divorce. The applicant confirmed that the legal statement, or statements, given in the application apply to either, or both the applicant and respondent.
en.whatThisMeansJurisdictionEachLegalStatme: Each legal statement includes some or all of the following legal connections to England and Wales.
en.whatThisMeansJurisdictionLivesAreMainlyB: If your lives are mainly based in England or Wales then you're what is legally known as 'habitually resident'.
en.whatThisMeansJurisdictionIncludeWorking: This may include working, owning property, having children in school, and your main family life taking place in England or Wales.
en.whatThisMeansJurisdictionExamplesAbove: The examples above aren't a complete list of what makes up habitual residence, and just because some of them apply to you doesn’t mean you’re habitually resident. If you’re not sure, you should get legal advice.
en.whatThisMeansJurisdictiondomicileIsUsual: Your domicile is usually the place in which you were born, regard as your permanent home and to which you have the closest ties.
en.whatThisMeansJurisdictionDomicileComplex: However, domicile can be more complex if you or your parents have moved countries in the past.
en.whatThisMeansJurisdictionWhenBorn: When you're born, you acquire a domicile of origin. This is usually:
en.whatThisMeansJurisdictionCountryYourFath: the country your father considered his permanent home if your parents were married
en.whatThisMeansJurisdictionCountryYourMoth: the country your mother considered her permanent home if your parents were unmarried, or your father had died
en.whatThisMeansJurisdictionDomicileOfOrigi: If you leave your domicile of origin and settle in another country as an adult, the new country may become your domicile of choice.
en.whatThisMeansJurisdictionNotSure: If you're not sure about your domicile you should get legal advice.
en.whatThisMeansJurisdictionEligibleResidua: Usually, to be eligible for residual jurisdiction, you or your husband/wife must be domiciled in England or Wales, and neither of you must be nationals of, or habitually resident in, another country in the EU (except Denmark).
en.whatThisMeansJurisdictionResidualJurisdi: However, residual jurisdiction can be more complex. If you’re not sure if this might apply to you, you should seek legal advice.
en.whatThisMeansJurisdictionCourtNeedsToKno: The court needs to know if there any other court cases which might affect the jurisdiction of the court, and its decision to grant a divorce.

en.jurisdictionConnectionOther: The courts of England and Wales have residual jurisdiction, meaning either: no other court in any EU Member State has jurisdiction and either {{ session.petitionerName }} or {{ session.respondentName }} is domiciled in England and Wales; or (for same sex couples only) {{ session.petitionerName }} or {{ session.respondentName }} married each other in England and Wales, no other court in any EU Member State has jurisdiction, and it would be in the interests of justice for the court to assume jurisdiction in this case.
en.otherCourtCases: Other court cases that could affect jurisdiction
en.onGoingCasesNo: There are no other ongoing, completed or abandoned court cases related to the marriage, property or children.
en.onGoingCasesYes: {{ session.petitionerName }} has given the following court cases which are related to the marriage, property or children.
en.whatThisMeansCostOrdersApplicantWasAsked: The applicant was asked if they want the court to order the respondent (and the co-respondent if applicable) to pay some or all of the divorce costs.
en.whatThisMeansCostOrdersFees: This could include all the fees during the divorce, such as the £550 application fee, solicitor fees, and any extra court fees.
en.whatThisMeansFinantialOrdersPropertyMone: The applicant was asked if they want the court to decide how your property, money, pensions and other assets will be split.
en.whatThisMeansFinantialOrdersChildren: These decisions are called 'financial orders'. Financial orders can be made for the applicant and for any children you may have.
en.whatThisMeansFinantialOrdersSolicitors: Most solicitors will recommmend that the applicant responds 'Yes' to this question.
en.whatThisMeansFinantialOrdersLegalProceed: To formally start legal proceedings, the applicant will need to complete another form (known as Form A) and pay a fee of £255. This means that they don't have to proceed with the financial order at this point.
en.whatThisMeansFinantialOrdersSpltMoney: If you both agree on how to split your money and property and want to make it legally binding, you can apply for a type of financial order called a 'consent order'.
en.whatThisMeansFinantialOrdersConsentOrder: You'll need to get a solicitor to draft the consent order, and then send it to the court with a £50 fee.
en.whatThisMeansFinantialOrdersLegalAdvice: You should get legal advice if you're not sure what to do.
en.whatThisMeansFinantialOrdersCertainCircu: The court can only make financial orders for children under certain circumstances. You'll usually either need to come to an agreement with your husband/wife (which you can then make legally binding with a consent order) or use the Child Maintenance Service.
